Hi,
 
I have written a library (http://truezip.dev.java.net) which relies on
finalize() and a shutdown hook to clean up its external resources (ZIP
files actually).
 
Unfortunately, when using the TestRunner.run(...) method, after my
tests have been successfully run for the first time, JUnit appears to
throw away my objects without their finalizer to be called. By
debugging my code I noticed that JUnit calls the static initializers
of my classes on the second run again, even if I deselect "Reload
classes every run".
 
From this I guess that JUnit throws away the class code and all
associated objects on the heap after the first run, no matter what
"Reload classes every run" says. I guess this is related to the class
loader, but I could not find a workaround.
 
Am I missing something? If not, is this a bug or a feature?
 
In my opinion an application should not be able to throw away objects
without providing some means to do cleanup, e.g. by calling finalize()
or offering some other sort of shutdown hook.
 
With best regards,
Christian Schlichtherle
